awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Networked Improvement Communities to Design and Implement Program Transformation Tools for Secondary Mathematics Teacher Preparation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mathematics Teacher Education Partnership (MTE-P) is a collaborative of over 90 universities organized by the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities.  It has worked to create solutions to significant problems in secondary mathematics teacher preparation. However, as noted in the Standards for the Preparation of Teachers of Mathematics prepared by the Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators (AMTE), creating programs that achieve the vision of well-prepared beginning mathematics teachers will be challenging. Such efforts will require a continuing focus that acknowledges the ongoing and cyclic nature of improving mathematics teacher preparation program. This project aims to address the challenges of transforming secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs to meet the recommendations outlined in the AMTE Standards. The project will address this challenge by weaving together two mutually-reinforcing areas of work using a networked improvement communities approach. A group of institutions involved in the MTE-P will develop approaches to effectively enact program transformation, drawn from research on institutional change and enacting the networked improvement communities design at an institutional level. The design of this project will thus be a network of networks, incorporating work across the institutions. Simultaneously, work will begin on developing a system to manage knowledge generated by the project and by the MTE-P more broadly. Through this project, a comprehensive approach will be developed to meet the national need of transforming secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs to meet the national vision of secondary mathematics teacher preparation. 

Over a period of two years, the project will build a basic infrastructure that has potential to be scaled up to support transformation efforts across the MTE-P and create a model that can be used throughout the nation. The project will engage secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs at five institutions (Auburn University, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, University of Kentucky, Mississippi State University, and California State University-Fullerton). Transformation of these five, diverse secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs has the potential to positively affect over 350 preservice teachers and over 25,000 K-12 students. The initial infrastructure created by this project will be the basis for future scale up to a larger number of sites. This project will also generate a knowledge management system to capture validated products and approaches useful in transforming secondary mathematics teacher preparation. Project leaders aim to extend access to the lessons learned and materials developed through this project to other institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The United States needs both more and better-prepared secondary mathematics teachers. Although the Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators outlined standards for preparing teachers of mathematics in 2017, more work is needed to support mathematics education programs to transform in the direction of these aspirational standards. From 2018 through 2021, the project entitled "Collaborative Research: Using Networked Improvement Communities to Design and Implement Program Transformation Tools for Secondary Mathematics Teacher Preparation" (NIC-Transform), led by Auburn University and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, has worked to support--and to better understand how to support--such program transformation efforts.

This project focused on building a community of institutions collaboratively developing and sharing tools useful in transforming secondary mathematics teacher preparation using a Networked Improvement Community (NIC) design. It also created a knowledge generation and management system to capture products and approaches found useful.

NIC-Transform initiated an application process which resulted in an additional 40 universities joining the five involved in the project at its inception. These universities represent 17 states and include 17 minority-serving institutions. Along with school and other partners, each of these universities is part of a local NIC focus on transforming their local secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs as part of a larger network supporting their work.

The project organized a range of events to support its activities. It hosted a three-day summer workshop in June 2019 in St. Louis to engage 81 participants in thinking about secondary mathematics teacher preparation. A subsequent three-day workshop was held virtually in June 2020 to begin engaging 135 participants in organizing local transformation efforts at their institutions, leading to their application to join the NIC-Transform network, leading to the recruitment of 40 additional teams. A virtual half-day Association of Mathematics Education Pre-Conference in February 2021 (129 participants) provided further support for the emerging teams and invited additional participants to learn more about the approaches being developed by the project. This was followed by a three-day virtual workshop held virtually in June 2021 to support the teams' continued growth in program transformation (77 participants). In addition, the project held 14 monthly webinars titled "NIC-Casts," which provided a closer look at issues in program transformation, leading local teams, and making progress toward aims (average attendance exceeded 20 participants). 

After two years of testing the Open Canvas platform as a knowledge generation and management system, the NIC-Transform project effectively utilized Open Canvas to provide access to a multitude of materials and to support a variety of meetings and groups. Open Canvas announcements also communicated with the broader set of Mathematics Teacher Education Partnership members. This increased level of familiarity among the NIC-Transform leadership resulted in greater access by local networked improvement communities and increased sharing of a variety of project products and materials. Moreover, the use of Open Canvas was especially evidenced in the online conferences and workshops offered by the project, which required participants to access materials in advance and during these events. The project also created a database of funded projects related to any aspect of teacher recruitment, preparation, or induction, where leadership teams can share materials and provide mentoring advice to other grants. This system has provided a stable platform from which to launch efforts to reach a broader community for NIC-Transform's future work.

By focusing on transforming secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs, NIC-Transform impacts future mathematics teachers participating in the targeted programs. Mathematics teachers who are better prepared can in turn better educate secondary mathematics students, thus contributing to workforce development in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Further, by providing a network, a knowledge generation and management system, and ongoing professional development, NIC-Transform supports the development of mathematics teacher educators and others engaged in the local partnerships to improve secondary mathematics teacher preparation programs. The goal, ultimately, is to impact the STEM workforce through an increase of secondary mathematics teachers who are well prepared to teach.
